body:
Ideas for a `submode` implementation, inspired from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/16263#issuecomment-963083127

A submode would be defined similarly to how `augroup` is defined.

    submode[!] <name>       start defining a submode called <name>
    submode END             end submode definition

`!` means that a previously defined submode with the same name is redefined,
otherwise redefining the same submode is an error.

Inside a `submode` block only mappings, abbreviations, commands and
autocommands can be defined (everything else is an error).

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For example:

```vim
submode! mysubmode
    nnoremap bla blabla
    inoreabbrev bla blabla
    autocmd BufLeave SubModeEnd
    command SubModeEnd call submodeend('mysubmode', 'buffer')
submode END
```

Note that `autocmd` has no pattern, because it has submode scope.

Autocommands wouldn't need to be put inside a group, because they would have
the submode scope. No need of `au!` either, because a submode could not be
redefined (`submode!` would clear everything inside the previously defined
submode). Also commands wouldn't need `!` for the same reason.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

You would enable it with:

    submodestart(<name>[, <scope>])

where `<scope>` would be global by default, or it can be `buffer` or `window`.

You would end it with:

    submodeend(<name>[, <scope>])

A mode that is enabled for a scope, would need to be disabled for that scope:

    call submodestart('mysubmode', 'buffer')
    call submodeend('mysubmode')                " ERROR: no global submode 'mysubmode'
    call submodeend('mysubmode', 'window')      " ERROR: no window submode 'mysubmode'

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Different submodes could be enabled at the same time in the same context, then
if two submodes define conflicting commands/mappings, the last one would win.

To make them stackable, each window/buffer would have a list of enabled
submodes, plus there would be a global list for the globally enabled submodes.
Each submode that is enabled in the current context is checked for a matching
command/mapping/autocommand. Submodes would be checked in reverse order, so the
last enabled submode would be checked first.

I think the original proposal by @bfredl was to introduce "namespaces" for mappings and events, which aligns more closely to **Neo**vim's API. ("Submodes" come from https://github.com/kana/vim-submode and are inspired by Emacs minor modes, but we should strive for _internal_ consistency.)

Similarly, the API design should be done in this order:
1. internal `nvim_XXX` API
2. Lua API
3. Vim script (if at all)

A `submode` is just another name for this kind of namespaces, as I see it. Once you do it for mappings, I think it makes sense to allow also autocommands and commands inside of them, since they can also be buffer-local and can benefit from having a submode scope. @bfredl was referring to emacs minor modes, judging from the [emacs documentation](https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/manual/html_node/emacs/Minor-Modes.html) they allow more than just mappings (I never used emacs though, so I'm not sure).

The API I described is just a simplification to illustrate the concept.

Well that's the thing with namespaces: they could be used for anything, though we incrementally implement one feature to them at a time. Though autocmds already have autocmd groups (and filters), so namespaces for mappings is the lowest hanging fruit here. for user ex commands plugins should just use properly disambiguated names anyway.
Has some work been done to implement namespaces already?
Well I only proposed ideas for a possible implementation, then I don't know if you have already something else in mind about them.

This issue has been mentioned on **Neovim Discourse**. There might be relevant details there:

https://neovim.discourse.group/t/disabling-and-re-enabling-groups-of-mappings/1721/2

I like how nvim_namespace_enable('foo', 'buffer') would allow you to enable mappings for a buffer without tying the <buffer> modifier to many individual map commands.  A plugin author could put a bunch of mappings into one or more namespaces that their plugin defines, and then let the user decide how they want those namespaces to be scoped.

If no one else has started work on this, I would like to take a crack at the implementation!

I have experience with C, but this would be my first time working with the nvim src.  Can anyone recommend regions of the code that I should become familiar with (in general and/or regions that are relevant to this feature)?
A lot of code related to mappings, abbreviations and input are in `src/nvim/getchar.c`.

in case anyone is interested: i got familiar with the relevant code in getchar.c and related regions (thanks zeertzjq!) but ultimately timed out (i.e. i have stopped working on it), partly because other issues took priority.

that said, i did put some work into refactoring, which may be helpful in case anyone else needs to work in this area; e.g. buf_do_map() performs 3 very different tasks with maphashes, and when those tasks are split into 3 different functions (which in my patch i've named 'activate_keymap()', 'deactivate_keymap()', and 'display_active_keymaps()'), those new functions are each very short (about a page long on average) and straightforward. So if anyone is interested in that, let me know!
@JamesWidman sure. you can always publish the code as a draft PR, then we can discuss how to utilize it best moving forward.
[done](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/17894)! (well, to the extent that a draft is "done")

> A submode would be defined similarly to how `augroup` is defined.

Please, god, no. More vimscript syntax is the last thing we need. 

This can be achieved with APIs and functions, without new syntax.
@justinmk ok it was just an initial idea to make it understandable
@justinmk agreed! (fwiw the draft pr doesn't even add a new feature, but if/when someone does that, then for sure we want to expose it only through an api)
couldn't we get something coming really close to this if we implement the idea of using the return value of `vim.on_key()`?
